properties.name: Piccadilly Gents Toilets
properties.description:
Approximate location of the old public toilets and hairdresser apparently still present (albeit hidden) in Piccadilly Station. You used to have to go down steps which have apparently simply been covered over.


You can see the entrance at the back of this image (thanks to Manchester Libraries).



(found here (http://northernrailways.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=15&t=5700#p70296))
properties.title: Piccadilly Gents Toilets

properties.name: Market Place
properties.description:
From Marks & Spencer plc and Market Place (http://manchesterhistory.net/manchester/tours/tour4/area4page3.html)

(http://manchesterhistory.net/manchester/tours/tour4/area4page3.html)
(http://manchesterhistory.net/manchester/tours/tour4/area4page3.html)
properties.title: Market Place

properties.name: Crypt under W G Ponter
properties.description: Under 22 Old Millgate a vaulted 'crypt' 30 feet below street level, accessed through the cellar. An advert appeared in a local paper in 1903 offering the chance to view the crypt. See Manchester Underground (Warrender, 2007:90).
properties.title: Crypt under W G Ponter

properties.name: Underground Street
properties.description:
Location very vague

Ojay (http://ojaybelowandbeyond.blogspot.com/2011/12/blog-post_16.html)
Undercroft (http://ojaybelowandbeyond.blogspot.com/2011/02/blog-post.html)
properties.title: Underground Street

properties.name: Lewis's Basement Canal
properties.description:
There was a recreation of a Venetian scene in the basement on gondola on a 2' deep 'canal'.


Manchester Underground (Keith Warrender, 2007:61).


As a point of interest the fifth floor still has a grand ballroom.


http://www.millhouseue.com/2012/01/lewiss-building-primark-manchester.html (http://www.millhouseue.com/2012/01/lewiss-building-primark-manchester.html)


(http://www.millhouseue.com/2012/01/lewiss-building-primark-manchester.html)
properties.title: Lewis's Basement Canal

properties.name: Palace Hotel
properties.description: Basement and sub basement contain extensive entertainment facilities.
properties.title: Palace Hotel

properties.name: Well under the old Theatre Royal
properties.description:
Site of Manchester's first theatre where a well was discovered under the stage. See Manchester Undergound (Warrender, 2007:76)


From A Well In Old Manchester (Baker, 1959) (http://www.abebooks.co.uk/OLD-MANCHESTER-WRIGHT-BAKER-H-PROFESSOR-D.Sc/599468680/bd).
properties.title: Well under the old Theatre Royal

properties.name: Underground Market Entrance
properties.title: Underground Market Entrance

properties.name: Chetham's Well
properties.description: Reported in the City News, 1915 that a passageway was discovered around 1842 between here and the Cathedral.
properties.title: Chetham's Well

properties.description:

properties.name: Moston Cottage
properties.description: A tunnel is remembered to exist in this area, beneath Moston Cottage (build 1713), and accessed through other properties. Rumoured to extend to the Cathedral and used as transport for catholics during persecution.
properties.title: Moston Cottage

properties.name: The Fountain
properties.description: Spring near the corner of King Street and Spring Gardens. See Underground Manchester (Warrender, 2007:76).
properties.title: The Fountain

properties.name: The Hovel
properties.description: A cobbled underground service road built in 1921 and written about in 1962 in the Manchester Evening Cronicle (Underground Manchester - Keith Warrender, 1962:66)
properties.title: The Hovel

properties.description: Rumoured that there was a passage from the cellar to the Cathedral.

properties.name: St Peters Crypt
properties.description: Demolished in 1907, St Peter's Church had 46 vaults underneath it packed with coffins.

properties.name: Mitre Hotel
properties.description: Has a tunnel underneath at the original street level, where the pub used to sit (Underground Manchester - Keith Warrender, 2007).
properties.title: Mitre Hotel

properties.name: Thatched House Pub
properties.description: Rough vicinity of the Thatched House Pub, demolished in 1972. There were apparently sandstone dunnels in the vaults which headed in the direction of the Cathedral and Spring Gardens (Warrender 2007:69).
properties.title: Thatched House Pub

properties.name: Mystery Steps
properties.description:
Steps which probably lead to the workings of the Piccadilly Gardens fountain.


(http://www.flickr.com/photos/manc/1182284990/)
